<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_lookup_connection_value:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN const char *
MHD_lookup_connection_value (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                             const char *key)
{
  const char *value;

  value = NULL;
  (void) MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                        kind,
                                        key,
                                        (NULL == key) ? 0 : strlen (key),
                                        &value,
                                        NULL);
  return value;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
(void) MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                        kind,
                                        key,
                                        (NULL == key) ? 0 : strlen (key),
                                        &value,
                                        NULL);
explanation: The only potential recursion concern in this function is the call to MHD_lookup_connection_value_n — it could introduce indirect recursion if that function (directly or indirectly) calls MHD_lookup_connection_value. Therefore the call site and the function definition are flagged for investigation. Other fragments do not need investigation for Rule 17.2: the local declaration and initialization of value, the ternary expression computing the key length, the call to strlen (a C library function that will not call user code here), the assignment and the return statement do not introduce direct or indirect calls to MHD_lookup_connection_value and so cannot cause self-calls by themselves. No other function calls are present in this snippet, so no additional fragments are relevant to Rule 17.2.
